title: The error says "found slice" but the solution is .as_slice()?

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
I was given a [suggested syntax to convert from a `Vec<&str>` to `&[&str]` by Ömer Erden on this question on StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/69535907/how-can-i-convert-vecstring-to-str/69536222#comment122907025_69535907)

```rust
fn main() {
  let pos: Vec<String> = vec!["foo".to_owned(), "bar".to_owned(), "baz".to_owned()];
  let pos: &[&str] = pos.iter().map(AsRef::as_ref).collect::<Vec<_>>()[..];
}
```

This produces the error,

```text
error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> bin/seq.rs:3:21
  |
  |     let pos: &[&str] = pos.iter().map(AsRef::as_ref).collect::<Vec<_>>()[..];
  |              -------   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  |              |         |
  |              |         expected `&[&str]`, found slice
  |              |         help: consider borrowing here: `&pos.iter().map(AsRef::as_ref).collect::<Vec<_>>()[..]`
  |              expected due to this
  |
  = note: expected reference `&[&str]`
                 found slice `[&_]`
```

Note that the diagnostic actually says _**expected `&[&str]`, found slice**_

However, the solution here is to remove `[..]` and add explicitly `.as_slice()`

```rust
fn main() {
  let pos: Vec<String> = vec!["foo".to_owned(), "bar".to_owned(), "baz".to_owned()];
  let pos: &[&str] = pos.iter().map(AsRef::as_ref).collect::<Vec<_>>().as_slice();
}
```

If the compiler finds a slice, the solution shouldn't be to add explicitly `.as_slice()`
